Ella también quiere que las mujeres D. escasos recursos aprendan este oficio, para que puedan mejorar sus vidas y las D. su familia, demostrar que las mujeres indígenas pueden sobresalir y no nada más  estar detrás D. un rincón abandonadas y rezagadas, así también ella quiere ver a sus hijos superarse y que tengan una mejor vida, lejos D. la pobreza y la necesidad, que no tengan que emigrar a otro lado, que sean personas D. bien y D. trabajo.
Todas las personas que integran este grupo son mujeres trabajadoras, en su totalidad indígena, llenas D. ánimo y una esperanza infinita, que creen en L. sueños y creen en la bondad D. las demás personas. 
 Julia, esta totalmente agradecida con el gesto noble D. ayuda que demuestran las personas que apoyan a fundación realidad, a L. que alrededor del mundo han puesto su granito D. arena por medio D. kiva para mejoramiento D. las vidas D. L. más desprotegidos. A nombre D. sus compañeras que integran su grupo les envía un fuerte abrazo.
A continuación aquí se dan a conocer L. nombres D. L. que integran el grupo D. “Abasolo” y sus actividades productivas: 

Lucia D. C.. – Elaboración D. antojitos
María Guadalupe Hernández D..- Venta D. comida
Luz D. L. S. L..- Venta D. antojitos
Elvira S. C..- Artesanías D. vestir 
Edna B. M..- Venta D. chiles y semillas
Gabriela Gómez Hernández.- Venta D. frutas y verduras
Hilaria D. Gómez.- Venta D. antojitos
Anatalia T. Hernández.- venta D. antojitos
Julia Dionicio Hernández.- Elaboración D. vestimenta artesanal
Lizbeth Hernández B..- Venta D. productos por catalogo
texts.en:
The following group is called “Abasolo” and their representative is called Edna B. M..  The group's name was chosen in honor of the street where the group's members live in the settlement of San Juan Jicayan which is located 45 minutes north of Pinotepa Nacional, Oaxaca.
The women's settlement is entirely maD. up of Mixtec indigenous people.  Most of the inhabitants work in crafts and in farming.  Amongst the hand-crafted items which they produce are 'jícaras' (traditional drinking bowls maD. from calabashes or gourds), textiles such as 'naguas' (skirts) and 'huipiles' (blouses or tunics).  These 'naguas' and 'huipiles' form part of their traditional dress.

The magic of this settlement lies in its traditions and customs but unfortunately its people have suffered great changes.  This is the case, for example, of the patenting of 'huipil' making.  They were displaced by foreign machines and have been robbed of the legacy of their symbology.  In this settlement, poverty prevails and they have been neglected by the authorities.  This means that its  inhabitants have emigrated to the United States and other places away from their communities.  Ignorance and a lack of education are ingredients which combine with the inequality which is found in the majority of the indigenous settlements in this region.  At the end of this story we will see the name of each one of the members of this group and the business activities which they pursue to make money.

On this occasion, let us make a space so that we can talk a little about the life of one of the members of this group.  Mrs Julia Dionicio Hernández is 32 years old.  She is married to 36 year-old Félix who has spent all his life working in the fields.  Julia has been married for 15 years and has 5 children who are currently studying.  Her children are: 15 year-old Miguel who is in the third year of high school, 13 year-old Adelina who is in her first year of high school, 10 year-old Florentino, 8 year-old Juana and 7 year-old Félix who are in their fifth, third and second years of elementary school.  They all speak Mixtec and their mother speaks only very little Spanish.

Since she was 10 years old, Julia has been making traditional garments which are now known as  handicrafts such as: 'naguas' (traditional skirts), backstrap loom weavings, 'huipiles' (traditional blouses or tunics), napkins and also hand-maD. threads.  This has been part of a legacy which has been passed down from generation to generation and which also provides money to support the family.  As we have already mentioned, Julia has spent her whole life making handmaD. textiles called 'backstrap loom weaving' but what is backstrap loom weaving and what do you make with it?

Let us talk a little more about backstrap loom weaving which is known as 'saahma tavi'.  This technique dates back to ancient times.  We can point out that it is from pre-hispanic times and has great value and its own style.  Rustic materials maD. from unique wood are used along with a unique finish.  Items of clothing are maD. such as 'naguas' (traditional skirts which are called 'chee' in Mixtec), 'huipiles' to cover the back and there are also backstrap loom weaving techniques for the making of 'huipiles' in the form of a dress which are called 'shicu lestu'.  In the making of these clothes, the dyes also have ancient origins since they are use dyes obtained from a sea shell known as 'caracol púrpura' (literally, 'purple shell') from which colors such as 'guinda' (a cherry color), 'morado' (a mulberry color) and purple are obtained.  They also use indigo, cochineal and 'árbol D. caracol' (another kind of shell-based dye).  In fact, these clothes just can't be compared to clothes created on an industrial machine.

Julia joined a loan group because she needed a loan to acquire the necessary material to make her crafts.  With this money she will be able to buy the following material: cotton threads for making 'huipiles', rustic threads for creating backstrap loom weavings, shell-dyed threads for making 'naguas', different colored threads for making napkins and tablecloths, embroidery threads and different colored worsted yarns and ribbons.

One of Julia's most longed-for dreams is to set up an organization of craftswomen where she can preserve and teach the valuable techniques of this art as well as promote these items of clothes which have been displaced by modernist fashion trends.  She would also like for women of few means to be able to learn this traD. so that they can improve their lives and those of their families, to show that indigenous women can shine and no longer need to be in a corner, abandoned and lagging behind.  She also wants to see her children be successful.  She wants them to have a better life, far from poverty and need, and for them not to have to emigrate.  She wants them to be good and hard-working people.

All the people who make up this group are hard-working women.  They are all indigenous women, full of vitality and an infinite hope, who believe in their dreams and believe in the goodness of other people.

Julia is totally grateful for this noble gesture of help which the people who are supporting Fundación Realidad are offering.  Those around the world who are putting in their grain of sand through Kiva to improve the lives of the most vulnerable.  In the name of her fellow group members, she sends you a big hug.

Below we give you the names of those who make up the “Abasolo” group and list their business activities:
Lucia D. C.. – making 'antojitos' (traditional Mexican snacks generally sold at street stands)
María Guadalupe Hernández D..- food sales
Luz D. L. S. L..- selling 'antojitos'
Elvira S. C..- hand making traditional clothes
Edna B. M..- selling chilis and seeds
Gabriela Gómez Hernández.- fruit and vegetable sales
Hilaria D. Gómez.- selling 'antojitos'
Anatalia T. Hernández.- selling 'antojitos'
Julia Dionicio Hernández.- making hand-crafted clothes
Lizbeth Hernández B..- selling catalog products

loans.use: To buy materials for making hand-crafted textiles; white cotton thread, natural cotton thread dyed with 'caracol púrpura' (a shell-based dye), mulberry- and cherry-colored threads for making 'naguas' (traditional skirts), different colored worsted yarns, ribbons, silk thread, thread skeins

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence is a resident of Nyamira Town in Western Kenya.  She is forty five years old and has been doing mixed farming for twenty eight years. She produces milk, beans, maize, and vegetables, and sells locally.

She has requested this loan of 45,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. She hopes to pay school fees with her income and also expand her farm through additional purchases to generate more income. She gets additional income from her second-hand clothes business.

Animal diseases are her challenges.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy slippers

loans.name: Mercedes

texts.en:
Mercedes has a long term partner, two children and lives in the rural area surrounding Hato Mayor, an agricultural area. This area, like nearly all impoverished areas of the Dominican Republic, suffers from unreliable running water (none of which is potable) and electricity.

For around twenty years Mercedes has operated a colmado, a shop where you can find basic food staples. Colmados are within short walking distances from neighborhood homes. Mercedes started her business with her savings. She plans to use this loan, her seventh, to buy rice, flour and other foods. She will use the profits to reinvest in her business. She is one of our entrepreneurs who has had her business improved through an individual loan.

Mercedes says that her biggest challenge is to buy a vehicle. In the meantime, she plans to continue enjoying doing business and spending time with her family. Mercedes’ story is generally representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican clients, many of whom recently emigrated to the Dominican Republic from Haiti.

loans.use: To buy rice, flour and other staples for her store

loans.name: Zinunula Community Bank, Nansana - Kampala Group

texts.en: N. Efrance, age 60, is a happily married mother of five who has been in dairy farming in Natete-Kampala for the past 20 years. She also has a side business selling firewood and water from which she ekes out additional profits. Before taking root in any of the aforementioned businesses, she was bearing a hand in a charcoal sales business, which she has since dispensed with. In the future, Efrance says she wants to expand her business horizons, and principally she is looking at constructing her own rental structures. For now, she says her focus is mainly on improving her current businesses. Weekly, this business generates 30,000 shillings for her. She says, with this loan, she is going to buy more firewood to resell. Efrance belongs to Zinunula Community Bank, Nansana - Kampala.

loans.use: To purchase firewood to resell

loans.name: John

texts.en: John is 30 years old, married and lives in Kyenjojo, Uganda, where he dreams of providing his children with an education through the university level. For the last four years, he has made a living buying and selling cattle. His business is booming, and he is applying for this loan to buy more cattle to sell.

loans.use: To buy and sell more cattle

loans.name: Richel

texts.en:
Richel B. is from the village of Lower Tiparak, Tambulig, Zamboanga Del Sur. She is 41 years old. Richel is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Richel owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Richel has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Richel joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Richel has successfully repaid a previous loan from GDMPC. This previous loan was used  to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise. Richel is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers, such as manure. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Richel from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers, such as manure

location.town: Lower Tiparak, Tambulig, Zamboanga Del Sur

loans.name: Maria Auxiliadora

texts.es: Este cliente es originario de la comarca el ojochal kilometro  112 carretera león san Isidro, es soltera tiene un hijo, actualmente se desempeña como  maestra de primaria en el colegio del poblado de san Jacinto Sara maría parrales, este cliente es el segundo crédito con la empresa atraves del convenio de financiamiento con dicho colegio, esta señora tiene de laborar en esta area 26 años , los financiamientos les han ayudado a mejorar su condición y nivel de vida
texts.en: This client comes from the Ojochal area, kilometer 112 on the León San Isidro Road. She is single and has one son. Right now she works as a primary school teacher at the Sara María Parrales school in  San Jacinto. This is her second loan with the organization through the financial agreement with the school. She has worked in this area for 26 years. The loans have helped her improve her quality of life and living conditions.

loans.use: Housing improvements - purchase doors and clay bricks

loans.name: Kuña Kuera Katupyry Group

texts.es:
Este Comité se formó gracias a la Señora Anisth Miryam V. D., que vive en la cuidad D. Villarrica.
Todas las integrantes, encantadas, aceptaron conformar el Comité D. Mujeres Rurales nombrando al Comité "Kuña Kuera Katupyry".
La sra. Maria Ediz se dedica a la venta D. ropas y cosméticos D. manera ambulante, ella desea prosperar en su comercio pues quiere superar la pobreza D. su familia, es una mujer muy sacrificada, trabaja mucho y sin descansos, como necesita aumentar las variedades D. sus productos solicitó el crédito D. Kiva, a fin D. equiparse con buena cantidad D. productos.
Con la ayuda que le ofreció la Fundación Paraguaya, este comité logro mejorar sus ingresos y  también mejorar sus condiciones D. vida.
texts.en:
This committee was formes thanks to Mrs. Anisth Miryam V. D., who lives in the city of  Villarrica.
All of the members happily accepted to be a part of the committee of rural women, calling the committee "Kuña Kuera Katupyry".

Mrs. Maria Ediz sells clothes and cosmetics as a door to door vendor. She wants to prosper in her business and overcome her family's poverty. She is a hardworking woman who works a lot without rest. Since she needs to increase the variety of her products, she asked for a loan from Kiva so that she can equip herself with a good quantity of products. 

With the help offered by the Fundación Paraguaya, this committee was able to improve her income and also her quality of life.

loans.use: To buy clothes and cosmetics for resale

loans.name: Cesar

texts.es: Cesar de 27 años, natural de la ciudad de Kimbiri es soltero y vive en la casa de sus padres; él es un joven muy optimista y con ganas de triunfar en la vida. Cesar, empezó su aventura culinaria vendiendo en las carretas de manera ambulante por las calles del distrito de Kimbiri y San Francisco. Su gusto por la buena sazón y la cocina le viene de sus raíces piuranas. Desde que ahorró decidió abrir su propio puesto de cevicheria y mariscos donde viene ofreciendo sus platillos en locales arrendados; cuenta que el primer día los clientes agotaron todo en par de horas y su local quedo chico. Ante esto consiguió un local más amplio y ahora cuenta con 02 ayudantes de cocina; le gusta su trabajo y tiene buena clientela que esperan mientras deleitan la vista observando el buen ambiente con imágenes turísticas que son de agrado a la vista de los clientes. El problema de su trabajo radica en no poder contar a la mano con los pescados que es el ingrediente fundamental para preparar los platos; es por ello que tiene que realizar viajes a la ciudad de Lima e Iquitos donde encuentra pescados de la mejor calidad. Con el dinero solicitado es para la compra de pescados y mariscos. Pero ahora lo que más prioriza es comprar su propio lote de terreno y así obviar el contrato del arrendamientos de locales. Este es su primer crédito de manera individual con MFP, pero a la vez es socio en los bancos comunales donde es muy puntual con sus cronogramas de pago. Con los 3,000 nuevos soles solicitados, comprará  pescados y mariscos de las ciudades de Lima e Iquitos.
texts.en: Cesar, 27, is a Kimbiri native.  He is single and lives with his parents.  He's an optimistic young man with a strong drive to get ahead in the world.  Cesar began his culinary adventures working as a street vendor, selling on the streets of the Peruvian towns of Kimbiri and San Francisco.  He has a flair for cooking local dishes such as ceviche and when he had enough saved to start a business, he rented space in a building and opened his own restaurant.  He tells us that, on the first day, he sold all the food he had in just a couple of hours.  He has a bigger space now and 2 kitchen assistants.  Cesar likes the work and his customers.  His restaurant is a friendly place where his customers look over pictures of local tourist sites while they wait.  His main problem is that there are no ready supplies of seafood, the basic ingredient of his menu.  He has to go to the cities of Lima and Iquitos where he can get supplies of good-quality products.  Cesar will use this loan to buy fish and other seafood.  His immediate priority, though, is to buy a space for the restaurant, a space that he would own rather than lease.  This is Cesar's first MFP loan, but he's a member of a community bank and has a history of repaying other loans.  He will use this 3,000 new soles loan to buy fish and other seafood in the the cities of Lima and Iquitos.

loans.use: to buy supplies of seafood for restaurant business

loans.name: Namatovu

texts.en:
Namatovu O. M. is 30 years old. She is married to David Wanyonyi and they have been blessed with two children. Namatovu O. runs a food kiosk back in Bamburi, and she has been in this business for the last two years.

This marks her second loan from KADET, and she plans to renovate the business premise. The anticipated income will be directed into the repayment of the loan. Her hopes and dreams are to improve her living standards.

loans.use: to renovate and expand her business premise

loans.name: Zayirbek

texts.en:
Zayirbek T. was born in and lives in the Republic of Tadjikistan. He grew up in a large family with eight children and from early childhood he had to help his parents in the field and in breeding cattle. After serving in the army, Zayirbek returned home and began to work as a driver at his local place. He was 25 years old when he married and he later became the father of three boys. 

In 1999 Zayirbek with his family moved to the central part of Kyrgyzstan, to Oktyabrskoe village. Using the money he had earned, Zayirbek bought a house and got a job as a driver. Using his salary, he was able to buy bull-calves for fattening and in 2008, he decided to devote his time to an animal breeding business. 

Being a very purposeful and positive person, Zayirbek works hard to support his family and today, he has three milk cows, one bull-calf and two sheep at his farm. Zayirbek plans to use this loan of 80,000 Kyrgyz Soms to increase the number of cattle. In the future, Zayirbek is planning to give higher education to his children and build a house for his family 

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population.

Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: to purchase cattle.

loans.name: Wakorintho Group

texts.en:
Joyce , who is in her early forties, is married with 3 adult children and one still in school.  She has three different kinds of businesses.  She has poultry, sells fabrics and liquid soap since 1996.  She works from 9.00am to 7.30pm daily and is able to make a fair monthly profit.

This will be Joyce's 1st loan from Tujijenge Tanzania.  She hopes for a loan to increase fabric stock, buy raw materials for making more liquid soap and to buy more chicks.  Her dream is to one day take her last born up to the university.

Joyce will take this loan with her loan group "Wakorintho" which has a total of 21 members, who will hold each other  accountable in paying back their loans.

In the picture, Joyce is 1st on the left, 1st row.

loans.use: To buy more chicks, fabrics and materials to make liquid soap.

loans.name: Munafa Development Group

texts.en:
Isata is the leader of this group of entrepreneurs.  She was born in a place called Shenama in eastern Sierra Leone.  She is 38 years of age.  Isata is married to a tailor and the couple has 2 children – 1 is not yet of school-age and the other is in secondary school. 

For 12 years now, Isata has been selling palm oil (the most popular cooking oil in the region) and beans. This is the first loan that Isata and her group members have applied for from SMT/Kiva lenders.  With the help of this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and consequently improve on their living conditions.  

Isata will use her share of the loan (SLL 500,000) to expand her business – she will buy palm oil and beans in large quantity to add to her business.

loans.use: buy palm oil and beans

loans.name: Marilou

texts.en:
Marilou is 24 years old and married with three children. With one child in school, Marilou works very hard to provide for them.

Marilou runs a business buying & selling sea cucumber in the Philippines. She requested a PHP 19,500 loan through NWTF to buy additional sea cucumber to sell.

Marilou has been in this business for four years.

In the future, Marilou would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: To buy additional sea cucumber to sell

loans.name: Mazera

texts.en:
Mazera is a married man with three children, all of whom attend school. He owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water.

For the past eight years, Mazera has operated a business buying and selling cows and goats. His potential customers are butcher shop operators. He dreams of expanding his business in the future.

Mazera decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost his business.  With a loan of 40,000 Kenyan shillings (KES), he plans to purchase two cows and sacks of maize.

loans.use: To purchase two cows and sacks of maize.

loans.name: Luis Eduardo

texts.es:
Vivir con sus padres y tener que velar por su bienestar motivó a Luis Eduardo a darle vida a su propio negocio. Motivado por las ganas de salir adelante, este emprendedor decidió empezar a ofrecerle a su comunidad de aserrador, labor que se encarga de cortar madera, y mantener los campos y jardines de Sonsón, municipio de Antioquia en perfecto estado. Pero sus aspiraciones van allá pues en el futuro espera tener varias motosierras que le ayuden a mejorar el servicio y hacer crecer su negocio, logrando así mejorar sus ventas y proporcionalmente su calidad de vida. 

Por ahora y empezando a dar los primeros pasos para cumplir sus sueño, Luis Eduardo ha ahorrado por varios meses para comprar su motosierra, sin embargo aún no es suficiente, motivo por el cual solicita un préstamo con el cual completar la totalidad del dinero y así ir construyendo paso a paso su futuro.
texts.en:
Living with his parents and having to see to their wellbeing motivated Luis Eduardoto give life to a business of his own.  Motivated by the desire to get ahead, this entrepreneur decided to start offering his community sawing services, work that involves cutting wood and maintaining the fields and gardens in Sonsón, a town in Antioquia, in perfect conditions.  However, his dreams go beyond this because in the future he’d like to own several chain saws that will help him improve service and make his business grow attaining better sales and proportionately improving his quality of life.

For now, starting to take the initial steps to make his dream come true, Luis Eduardo has saved up for several months to buy a chain saw.  However, it’s still not enough and this is why he’s asking for a loan to make up the difference in the total amount of money he needs so that he can be building his future step by step.

loans.use: to buy a chain saw.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: buy a variety of clothes especially baby clothes.

loans.name: Margarita

texts.en: Margarita is 47 years old and married with four children. She has a small stand in the local market in her town where she sells bread every day of the week. She bakes all of her own bread fresh daily and is especially known for her sweet bread. She is asking for a $1,200 loan in order to build a new oven in the kitchen of her house. Currently, she must rent an oven outside of her house to make bread and a new oven will save her time and money in the long run. Specifically, she will buy cement, wood, and other materials to build her oven. Margarita is committed to making the necessary loan payments on time.

loans.use: to buy cement, wood, and other materials to build a large oven in her house

loans.name: Uguloy

texts.ru: Угулой жительница Шахритусского района. Ей сорок лет. Она вдова. У нее один ребенок. Угулой занимается торговлей на рынке. Она в основном занимается торговлей детской одежды. Этим видом деятельности она занимается 12 лет. В торговле ей помогает ее сын. Она берет кредит для приобретения сезонного товара детям подросткового возраста.
texts.en: Uguloy lives in the Shahrituz region. She is forty years old. She is a widow with one child. Uguloy sells goods in the market, primarily children's clothing. She has been in this line of work for 12 years. Her son helps her with her work. She is asking for a loan to purchase seasonal goods for teenagers.

loans.use: Purchase seasonal clothing for teenagers.

loans.name: Kalameli

texts.en:
Kalameli is 38 years old and married with two children. Kalameli owns and operates a business venture, selling fried foods in the local community. She has four years of experience in this business. Kalameli needs a loan of 2500 Samoa tala (WST) to purchase boxes of chicken leg quarters, sausages, mutton flaps, and plastic plates. She plans to use the profit from her business (estimated to be 250 talas or US $104 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2008, Kalameli joined SPBD to gain access to financial services. Most of SPBD's clients are unable to borrow from commercial banks, because they lack collateral. This is Kalameli's fourth loan with SPBD.

loans.use: to purchase boxes of chicken leg quarters, sausages, mutton flaps, and plastic plates.

loans.name: Alicia

texts.en:
Alicia works hard to support her family. Alicia is married and has a fish vending business in the Philippines.

Alicia requested a PHP 11,000 loan through NWTF to buy more fish to sell to customers.  Alicia has been in this business for 5 years.  In the future, Alicia would like to repair and renovate her family home.

loans.use: to buy more fish to sell to customers

loans.name: Artykbubu's Group

texts.en: Artykbubu is the leader of this group. She is 56 and married to a veterinarian. Together they have raised two sons and two daughters. The daughters are married; they live separately with their families. The older son works in Russia and the younger son is engaged in farming. Artykbubu works at a school; she is also engaged in a livestock business. At the moment, she keeps a cow with a calf and 15 farm animals. With money received from the loan, she wants to purchase four goats to increase her number of livestock. In the near future, Artykbubu plans to start repairing the house. Where Did This Loan Come From? This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple "P" bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase goats.

loans.name: Filomena

texts.en:
Filomena is 51 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with three children. 
Filomena has a shop that sells canned goods, snacks and beverages. She has run this business for seven years. She has requested a loan of 14,000 PHP to buy canned goods, snacks and beverages.
Filomena has been a member of HSPFI since 2010. In the future, she hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks and beverages.

loans.name: Dominic

texts.en:
Dominic is 60 years old, married and has three children.  To earn a living, he uses his lorry for a transport business.  He has been in the business for six years and has employed one person. He has managed to improve his business through the financial support from Faulu Kenya. His desire is to venture into other businesses in five years.

He has requested 60,000 Kenya shillings to service his lorry.

loans.use: To service his lorry

loans.name: Priscillah

texts.en:
Priscillah is a 27-year-old married woman with two school-going children. Her husband, Paul, is a businessman who contributes to the provision of the family's basic needs. She owns a house with neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for her family.

Priscillah has operated a retail shop for the past three years; her potential clients are the local area villagers. She faces a major challenge in the fluctuating prices of commodities. She dreams of establishing a wholesale shop in the future.

With the 40,000 Kenyan shillings, she wants to purchase rice, wheat flour, maize flour and cooking oil for her shop. She decided to join Yehu Microfinance to access loans to boost her living standards.

loans.use: To purchase rice, wheat flour, maize flour and cooking oil for her shop.

loans.name: Consessa

texts.en: Consessa is married and has three children between the ages of 1 and 8. Her husband is a home builder. She sells vegetables in a market where she has been working for the last 10 years. Consessa would like a loan to expand the types of vegetables she sells in her store. She would like to use any profits to renovate her house.

loans.use: To buy more vegetables for resale

loans.name: Rosario Yen

texts.es:
Rosario Yen tiene 40 años de edad vive en unión libre tiene cinco hijos vive con el esposo y con los hijos de 23, 22, 19, 15 y 9 años de edad en el Cantón Ventanas Provincia de los Ríos.

La VRC LUCHANDO JUNTOS, se encuentra ubicada en el Recinto Zapotal nuevo, Pertenece al Cantón Ventanas se dedican a Labores Comerciales en su mayoría. 

Rosario se dedica a atender en un comedor de comida, vende desayunos, almuerzos y meriendas de lunes a Sábado, Las compras de las productos los realiza en Ventanas. Solicita el crédito para comprar pollos, carnes, frutas como la sandía, melon, frutillas, verduras y comprar mesas, sillas, manteles para que los comensales esten cómodos al momento de servirse los alimentos preparados.


Con la ayuda del crédito le ayudará a obtener mayores beneficios. El sueño es poder agrandar el negocio, no se le ha presentado ningún tipo de problema  en el negocio.
En los tiempos libres le gusta ayudar en la agricultura.
texts.en:
Rosario Yen is 40 years old.  She has a partner and five children who are 23, 22, 19, 15, and 9 and they all live together in Ventana Canton in the Los Ríos Province.

The Luchando Juntos Communal Bank is located in the newer Zapotal area in the Ventanas Canton.  They primarily deals with commercial work.

Rosario runs a canteen for a living.  They do their buying and selling in Ventanas.  She is asking for the loan to improve this business.

The loan will help her make greater profits.  Her dream is to expand her business and she hasn't had any problems at all with her business.

In her free time she likes to help out in agriculture.

loans.use: to purchase meats, chickens, fruits and vegetables, and chairs, tablecloths, and tables

loans.name: Tumaini Shg Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Tumaini SHG Group in Western Kenya! Evelyn is the facilitator of the Tumaini SHG group. This group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Evelyn takes care of five children at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for her family. In the recent 2011 season, Evelyn had a good maize yield harvesting 20 bags on one acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Evelyn was only able to harvest 7 1/2 bags of maize on one acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Evelyn and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from her maize sales, Evelyn will educate her children, ensure food security and invest in livestock rearing.

In 2012, the members of Tumaini SHG group will each plant between ½ and 1 acre of maize.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Marvin Mauricio

texts.es:
Marvín, es agricultor, vive con su padre, es soltero, comenzó a trabajar la agricultura por su padre, quien le enseño desde muy joven, no tienen un horario fijo y en la actualidad está iniciando la nueva siembra.
Él solicita un préstamo para sacar la cosecha anterior y para prepararse con la nueva, trabajando  la tierra y de esta manera tendrá un mejor trabajo ya casi listo, esperando que sus cultivos sean provechosos.
La aspiración de él es adquirir cada vez más experiencia para ser un agricultor exitoso y apoyar a su padre en todo momento.
texts.en:
Marvín is a farmer.  He is single and lives with his father.  He started farming through his father who taught him how when he was very young.  They do not work regular hours and, right now, Marvín is starting to sow a new lot of crops.  He is requesting a loan to gather in his previous harvest and prepare the soil for sowing his new crops.  In this way, he will be able to better carry out his work and wait for his crops to be profitable.

Marvín's aspirations are to acquire more and more experience so that he can become a successful farmer and to support his father at all times.

loans.use: to gather in his harvest and start preparing the soil to sow his new crops

loans.name: Las Palmeras Group

texts.es:
La A.C. “LAS PALMERAS” iniciará su primer ciclo en Pro Mujer, como parte del centro focal Panamericana, está compuesta por seis integrantes y está dirigida por una mesa directiva donde la señora Juana es la tesorera. Los negocios que las integrantes de la asociación comunal llevan adelante son variados entre ellos tenemos: tejido de mantas, chiflera y amautas, atención de llamadas, comidera, artesana de chompas, venta de velas.

La señora Juana,  indica que es la primera vez trabaja en Pro Mujer y que integro la institución por invitación de la promoción. En la actualidad ella tiene un negocio de venta de comida que viene trabajando hace años y aprendiendo el mismo de su familia.

El crédito que ahora sacará es para aumentar su capital (compra de viveres) que adquiere de la Ceja  y posteriormente a la elaboración lo comercializará en su puesto de venta. Esta forma de trabajo le permite generar recursos para apoyar a su familia, pues ella es casada y tiene tres hijos.  

Cuando se le consulta qué le gusta de Pro Mujer, ella responde que le gusta las reuniones.

En la fotografía no esta la señora Raquel, ya que se tuvo que ir con urgencia a su fuente laboral.
texts.en:
The “LAS PALMERAS” group will start their first loan cycle in Pro Mujer, as a part of the Panamericana Focal Center. This group has 6 members and is headed by a board of directors with Ms. Juana as the treasurer. The women have a variety of businesses.  Among them are: blanket weaving, amautas and chiflera (natural healing), telephone answering service, operating a diner, making handcrafted sweaters, and selling candles.

Juana said that this is the first time she has worked in Pro Mujer and that she joined the institution by invitation. Currently she owns a business selling food, which she learned from her family and has done for years. 

The loan that she will take out will be used to grow her capital (to buy supplies) which she will acquire from Ceja.  Subsequent to the development, she will commercialize her sales post. This form of work allows her to generate resources to support her family, as she is tired and has three children.  

When she was asked what she likes about Pro Mujer, her response was that she enjoys the meetings.  

Ms. Raquel is not pictured because she had to go quickly due to an emergency situation.

loans.use: To buy supplies.

loans.name: Sorry For Me Group

texts.en:
Meet the members of the “Sorry For Me” group from Waterloo, a small town in Western Sierra Leone where Shine on Sierra Leone has partnered with SMT to start a branch. They are all local entrepreneurs who have come to SMT, a partner of Kiva.org, to apply for a loan of 2,700,000 SLL for the entire group. With the help of this loan they will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and consequently improve their living conditions. 

Sento is the leader of this group. The 25 year old is married to a businessman and together they have four children, two of whom are attending primary schools. 

Sento has been a businesswoman for thirteen years now. She sells market food such as rice, palm-oil (the country’s most popular cooking oil), peppers, gari (food made out of cassava roots), etc. With her share of this loan, she will buy the above mentioned items at wholesale to add to her current stock. 

(Also included in the left of the photo is loan officer Kadiatu Bah, handing over the loan to the borrowers)

loans.use: to buy rice, palm-oil, peppers, gari, etc., at wholesale to add to her current stock.

loans.name: Melinda 	Rocio

texts.es: La señorita Melinda es una joven emprendedora que se dedica a la confección de prendas de vestir,  que vive con sus 2 hermanos y su madre a quienes s ayuda con los gastos del hogar, ya que esta es su única actividad para poder ayudar en la economía de su hogar,  ella se dedica a la confección de  vestidos para niñas y para mayores hace ya 2 años, con el crédito tiene pensado comprar telas, cintas, encajes y para poder realizar unos  trabajo para las oficinas ya que tiene muchos pedidos por esta temporada y así poder aumentar su capital y sus ingresos de su familia, con el tiempo ampliar su negocio y culminar sus estudios.
texts.en:
Señorita Melinda is a young entrepreneur, who works making clothing items.  She lives with her two brothers and her mother, whom she helps with the household expenses.  This is her only activity that allows her to help with the household finances.

She has been working sewing clothes for children and for adults for the last two years.  With the loan she intends to purchase fabric, ribbons and lace, so that she can do some work for the offices from which she gets many orders at this time of year.  In this way she can increase her capital and her family's income, and with time she can expand her business and complete her studies.

loans.use: to purchase materials for making clothing: fabric and thread

loans.name: K. Roselyne's Group

texts.fr: Ce groupe est formé de trois personnes qui résident dans le même quartier. La représentante de ce groupe, nommée K. Roselyne, est celle dont la main est levée sur la photo. C’est la première fois que ce groupe sollicite l’appui financier de ALIDé en vue d’élever le niveau de leur activité. K. Roselyne est âgée de 29 ans et est mariée à un certain Serge. Le couple a un enfant, scolarisé et à leur charge. K. Roselyne vit ensemble avec son enfant et son mari. Les diverses charges de la maison sont assumées par K. Roselyne et son mari. Pour cette raison, K. Roselyne depuis cinq ans vend des cartes de recharges, du gari (farine de manioc) et des savons à son domicile ce qui lui permet de répondre sans grande difficulté à ses besoins ainsi qu’à ceux de ses enfants. K. Roselyne s’approvisionne dans un marché du Bénin. Dans le souci de mieux répondre aux exigences de sa clientèle, K. Roselyne désire renforcer ses stocks de produits et rehausser le niveau de son activité. Pour ce faire, K. Roselyne sollicite, ensemble avec les autres membres de son groupe un premier crédit auprès de ALIDé.

loans.use: Acheter des cartes de recharges, du savon et du gari.

loans.name: Sreynoch

texts.en: A young student from Phnom Penh city, Sreynoch is 19 years old and still study in university. To support on her living and her study, she has working as a teacher in school. For Sreynoch, this is her first micro loan with VisionFund. She will manage her loan to pay on tuition fee on her Marketing skill which she will go to study in abroad. Sreynoch wishes that she can finish her studying successfully and she can get a good job with higher salary for her family.

loans.use: To pay on tuition fee on her Marketing skill.

loans.name: Ma. Guadalupe

texts.en:
Guadalupe is a 51-year old woman, charismatic, friendly and hard working. She has a small business, now five years running, through which she sells convenience store items. Her youngest son helps her on his spare time when he is not in school. Faced with her husband\'s unemployment, she thought of the idea to sell convenience store items. Slowly her business has gained strength and her customers have increased.

She requires a loan of $750USD to buy merchandise wholesale. She will be able to provide her customers with better prices for the products and her sales will increase. She needs your help and your support.

Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer.

Doña Guadalupe es una mujer de 51 años, carismática, amigable y trabajadora. Tiene un pequeño negocio el cual consiste en la venta de abarrotes y desde hace más de 5 años Doña Guadalupe inició su negocio; su hijo menor le ayuda en sus tiempos libres ya que en la actualidad el jovencito se encuentra estudiando. Ella enfrento la situación de que su esposo había perdido su trabajo por lo que se le ocurrió la idea de vender abarrotes, poco a poco su negocio a cobrado fuerza y es que sus clientes han estado aumentado.

Ella necesita un préstamo de $750 USD para comprar mercancía a muy bajo precio, es decir, mercancía a mayoreo, donde esto le permitirá tener mejores precios de sus productos y sus ingresos se incrementaran. Ella requiere de tu ayuda y apoyo.

loans.use: Purchase Merchandise

loans.name: Tarana

texts.en:
Tarana has 5 years of experience in this business. 
She is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan, Fizuli region settled in the Fizuli region, Alkhanli  village. She is married and has 2 children.
Having borrowed $600 she bought a meaty bull-calf.
Now she needs a loan of $800 to buy 4 calves.

loans.use: To buy 4 calves

loans.name: Identity

texts.en:
This borrower is 35 years old and lives in the very poor area in Kirkuk. He is responsible for a big family. He lives with his mother and his sister and his wife and one child. He has a small minimarket in the south of Kirkuk, which he got from his father. This is his first loan from Al-Aman. He wants to purchase an ice box to sell ice cream. He wants to earn money to allow his sister to continue to study and get her high school diploma.

Disclaimer: This entrepreneur is from a volatile region where the security situation remains unsettled. Lenders to this business should be aware that this loan may represent a higher risk and accept this additional risk in making their loan.

Note: Personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him or her (i.e. blacking out portions of the entrepreneur in his/her picture, altering his/her first or last name, etc.).

loans.use: Purchase ice box

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more merchandise to stock up her store

loans.name: Ni Luh Yeni

texts.id:
Ni Luh Yeni, a housewife and a farmer, has side job of pig farming that helps her family economy. The working capital from DINARI is to be used to buy 3 piglets in addition to her female pig that already gave birth to 5 pigs.

Part of the working capital is to be used to buy pig feed that cost to Rp 25,000 (US$ 3) per day. The feeding is done twice a day, in the morning and in the afternoon. The total estimated cost to grow these pigs is Rp 3,000,000 (US$ 316) which can generate gross income of Rp 4,850,000 (US$ 511), so the net profit will be Rp 1,850,000 (US$ 195).

Ni Luh Yeni is very happy with her business and she hopes that her cooperation with DINARI can be sustainable and her business is growing.

Translated from Indonesian by Antonius Gunadi, Kiva volunteer.

Ni Luh Yeni seorang ibu rumah tangga yang memiliki usaha beternak babi yang dirasakannya sangat membantu perekonomian keluarganya disamping sebagai seorang petani. Modal usaha dari DINARI dipergunakan untuk membeli 3 bibit penggemukan, karena Ni Luh Yeni mempunyai induk babi dan sudah beranak 5 ekor. Sebagian modal dipergunakan untuk membeli pakan ternak yang setiap hari membutuhkan biaya sebesar Rp.25,000,- dan diberi makan 2 kali setiap hari yaitu pagi dan sore. Biaya pengeluaran sampai panen baik anak induk babi dan babi penggemukan sebesar Rp.3,000,000,-. Pendapatan kotornya sebesar Rp.4,850,000,- jadi keuntungan bersih sekali panen sebesar Rp,1,850,000,-.Ni Luh Yeni sangat senang dengan usahanya ini harapannya supaya kerjasama dengan DINARI dapat berkesinambungan dan usahanya lebih maju.

loans.use: to buy piglets and pig feed

loans.name: Matauaina

texts.en: Matauaina is a married mother of 45 years of age who has 6 children. Her family has been in a fishing business for a very long time and this was their only source of income. Her husband is a carpenter and his salary every week is not sufficient to support the family. Matauaina believes that fishing can earn more money than any other business. This is the reason why she spends all her time to make sure her fishing business can be very successful in the future. Matauaina is very thankful that one day, she will have a bigger boat and own much more fishing gear than she has now.

loans.use: To repair her canoe and buy new fishing gear

loans.name: Gaurbek

texts.en: Gaurbek N. lives in Mastchokh; he is married and has 3 children. He has been an active client of MicroInvest since 2005 and business stability allows him to increase the loan sum. Mr.N. is engaged in business of the menswear selling. He has a wide-side assortment that allows him to work with people of different income levels. He dreams to have a roomy home where his family could live happily. Mr. Nazatov requests a loan of US$600 to make a good roof for his home.

loans.use: To make a good roof for his home

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buy cosmetic  products and then sell them

loans.name: Iyetunde

texts.en: Iyetunde A. is 40 years old, married and has a child. She hails from Iba Area in Lagos State, Nigeria. She sells drinks. She needs a loan of $450 to enable her buy more drinks for sale. She has been in business for 4 years. She thanks you.

loans.use: To buy more drinks for sale

loans.name: Ferhad

texts.en: Ferhad A. comes from a loz income family. He is a 43 year-old man, who is married and has two children. He is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from Fuzuli a region in Azerbaijan. He settled with his family in Beylagan, a small city in Azerbaijan in 1993. He has been driving a taxi for a few years to earn a living. Ferhad applied to the Normicro Beylagan Branch for a KIVA loan of $400 in order to purchase necessary spare parts for his vehicle.

loans.use: To repair his vehicle

loans.name: Yulissa Beatriz's Group

texts.es:
Yulissa and Elisa have belonged to the Brilliant Communal Bank for 6 months and 1 year, 6 months respectively. They are from the community of Mollepata that this located 20 minutes from the city of Ayacucho.

Yulissa lives in a shared home. She is 26 years old and has 3 children. Yulissa and her husband manufacture native bricks that they sell to distributors.

Meanwhile Elisa also lives in a shared home. She is 32 years old and has 1 daughter of 6 years. Elisa has a store where she sells meat, groceries and vegetables.

Yulissa and Elisa need loans of 900 soles and 600 soles; money that will be invested in the purchase of firewood, rice, noodles, sugar and eggs.

The dreams of Yulissa and Elisa are to build their own houses, that their children become professionals and to expand their businesses.

Translated from Spanish by B, Kiva Volunteer.

Yulissa y Elisa pertenecen al Banco Comunal Brillantes hace 6 meses, 1 año, 6 meses respectivamente. Ellas son de la comunidad de Mollepata que esta ubicada a 20 minutos de la ciudad de Ayacucho.

Yulissa es conviviente, tiene 26 años y 3 hijos, Yulissa junto a su esposo fabrican ladrillos artesanales y lo venden a intermediarios.

Mientras que Elisa es conviviente, tiene 32 años y 1 hija de 6 años, Elisa tiene una tienda donde vende carne, abarrotes verduras.

Yulissa y Elisa necesitan préstamos de 900 soles, 600 soles, dinero que será invertido en la compra de leña, arroz, fideo, azúcar, huevo.

Los sueños de Yulissa y Elisa son construir su casa, que sus hijos sean profesionales y ampliar sus negocios.

loans.use: To buy firewood, rice, noodles, sugar and eggs for their brick and grocery businesses.

loans.name: Thị Thu

texts.vi:
Mrs. Le Thi Thu is 51 years old. She is taking orders to make "Chung" cake (Vietnamese special occasion cake for Lunar New Year), while her husband is the owner at a small restaurant. Her son already married and moved out. Mrs. Thu's family income is about 100,000 - 150,000 VND per day (equivalent to about $6 - $9). She wants to borrow 2,006,000VND (about $125) to buy rice to make "Chung" cake and run the restaurant. What Mrs. Thu like most about this program is that she is allowed and encouraged to pay back w/ small installments :). Ms. Vu Thi Hoa is 33 years old. She also wants to borrow $125 to fund for her small stall at the market. Mrs. Hoang Thi Mai is 38 years old. She also needs $125 to run her small stall at the market. Mrs. Le Thi Nhan is 45 years old, and she would also love to have $125 to buy goods for her stall at the market. Mr. Le Danh Di is 49 years old this year. He also wants to borrow $125 to buy chickend food.

Translated from Vietnamese by Phuong Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer.

Cô Lê Thị Thu (MS: 09010001), năm nay 51 tuổi. Cô làm nghề gói bánh Trưng để bán theo đăt hàng của khách, chồng cô bán hàng ăn. Cô có con trai đã lập gia đình. Thu nhập bình quân của gia đình cô khoảng 100.000-150.000 VND. Cô vay 2.006.000 VND để lấy vốn mua gạo làm bánh Trưng và bán hàng ăn. Cô thích vay vốn của chương trình vì được trả góp. Chị Vũ Thị Hoa (MS: 09010002), năm nay 33 tuổi. Chị vay 2.006.000 VND để có thêm vốn bán hàng ở chợ. Chị Hoàng Thị Mai (MS: 09010003), năm nay 38 tuổi. Chị vay 2.006.000 VND để lấy vốn đi chợ. Cô Lê Thị Nhân (MS: 09010004), năm nay 45 tuổi. Cô vay 2.006.000 VND để lấy vốn đi bán hàng ở chợ. Bác Lê Danh Dị (MS: 09010011), năm nay 49 tuổi. Bác vay 2.006.000 VND để mua cám cho gà.

loans.use: retail and breeding animals

loans.name: Bahtiyor

texts.ru:
Bahtiyor I. lives in the Kolhozabad district. He is 39 years old, married with 2 children, and has finished college. He is a taxi driver, but also raises animals. This side business helps him earn additional income. A hot summer has caused problems with the animals’ feed supply. Hay is expensive, and stocking up on it requires money. So this entrepreneur decided to take out a loan. He will repay it over 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer.

Ибрагимов Бахтиер житель района Коллхозабад. Возраст 39 лет , женат и имеет 2 детей. Образование высшее. Работает таксистом. Кроме того занимается животноводством .Параллельный бизнес помогает ему получать дополнительный доход. В связи с жарким летом возникла проблема с кормом для животных. Покупка сена стоит дорого, а для того , чтобы запастись сеном нужны деньги. Для этого клиент планирует получить кредит. Погасить его он сможет в течении 12 месяцев.

loans.use: Feed Purchase

loans.name: Augustina

texts.en:
Augustina is forty years old. She is a wife and mother of two children. She is a resourceful mother and a successful business woman. She works hard to support her children in school. At the moment, her two children are in senior high school.

Augustina sells linen, sewing materials and flowers. She has inadequate working capital to support her business growth. She believes that with the loan, she will better be able to supply her customers with quality products. She hopes to increase her income, since quality comes with a higher price she can charge her customers. Augustina wants to use the loan to buy more pieces of linen clothes, sewing materials and flowers.

Augustina belongs to the community group called Beloved Trust Group. In this group, members agree to act as social collateral to guarantee access to loans and to help repay the loans for one another.

loans.use: To buy more pieces of linen clothes, sewing materials and flowers.

loans.name: Warda's Jitahidini Group

texts.en:
Warda is 23 years old. She is a married and sells ladies' clothes for a living. She works daily from 6AM to 4PM at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $23 (US Dollars) in sales.

Warda has successfully taken out one previously loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She hopes for a new loan to buy more ladies' clothes for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members: Fatma, Mwanayam, Khadija, Patima, and Maryam.

loans.use: To buy more ladies' clothes for her business.

loans.name: Pham Thi

texts.vi: Chị T.  tham gia vào quỹ từ năm 1999. Hiện tại kinh tế gia đình chị T. vẫn còn nhiều khó khăn do đông con và các con còn nhỏ . Hàng ngày anh chị đi làm thuê cho  các xưởng may ở trong thôn với thu nhập 1.800.000  đồng/tháng.  Để tăng thêm nguồn thu nhập cho gia đình và cải thiện cuộc sống  trong thời gian tới anh chị dự định làm lại chuồng trại để chăn nuôi thêm 2 -3 con lợn. Vì thế chị mong muốn được vay mức vốn 6.000.000đ để đầu tư sửa sang chuồng trại và mua lợn về nuôi
texts.en:
Mrs.T. joined the Fund in 1999. Currently, her family's economy is still in a very difficult state, as there are many children and they are still small. Every day, husband and wife work as contractors for various factories around their village. Their income is 1.800.000đ per month. In order to increase the family's income and improve their living conditions, they plan to set up a facility to breed an additional 2-3 pigs. Therefore, they would like to borrow 6.000.000đ to invest into the refurbishing of a facility and purchase pigs for raising.

Translated from Vietnamese by Minh Bui, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Raising

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en: Virginia, 25, is married with 1 child.  She has 4 years of experience in the BBQ business. She sells to the villagers and the public 5 days per week. She has had 1 previous loan with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 600 Tala (~250 USD).  SPBD loans are Verginia's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She will use her loan to buy boxes of mutton flaps, chicken franks, sausage, onions and soya for her BBQ business. Her older sister is helping her with the business.

loans.use: Purchase to buy mutton flaps,chicken franks, sausage, soya, onions, salt,etc

loans.name: Ana Maria

texts.es:
Ana belongs to the community bank Atenas Portillanasu, located at Raul Porras Barrenechea Number 170 in the district of Yarina Cocha of the department of Ucayali. She is 62 years old, a mother of 9 grown children, and married. Her husband works as a farmer. With the first loan of about $100 USD from Manuela Ramos, she invested in a grocery business. She has been working with the bank for 7 years. She owns two transport motorcycles and with the help of her two grandsons, who work daily providing transportation, she makes enough to repay her loan on time. With this loan of $500 USD, which she will repay in 5 months, she can buy 4 tires, headlights, have the seats recovered, and fix and maintain the engines. Thanks to Manuela Ramos, she has realized one of her dreams, that of having two transport motorcycles of her own and thanks to them her financial situation has improved.

Translated from Spanish by a Kiva volunteer.

La señora Ana pertenece al Banco Comunal “Atenas Portillanas”, ubicado en el Jr. Raúl Porras Barrenechea Nº 170 del Distrito de Yarina Cocha del Departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 62 años y es madre de 9 hijos mayores de edad, es casada, su esposo se dedica al trabaja de agricultor. Ana con el primer préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos de S/300 decide invertir en la venta de abarrotes. Tiene 7 años trabajando con el Banco.nnEn la actualidad ella cuenta con 2 motokar y con la ayuda de sus nietos, quienes trabajan todos los días en el manejo de su movilidad, brindándole ganancias para cumplir con el préstamo y pagar puntualmente.nnCon este préstamo de S/1.500 el cual será pagado en 5 meses comprará: 4 llantas, focos, tapizar los asientos, arreglo de motor y otros mantenimientos. nnGracias a Manuela Ramos hizo realidad uno de sus sueños, tener 2 movilidades propias y gracias a ello su estabilidad económica ha mejorado.n

loans.use: Purchase tires, headlights and engine maintenance.

loans.name: Khnar

texts.en: Mrs. Khnar S. lives in Kvav village in Takeo Province. She is a Khmer cake seller who earns a small income to support her family from this business. Her husband, Mr. Meas Chanthon, is a farmer who owns a small piece of land on which he cultivates rice; he is also a basketmaker. Even taken together, the couple's incomes are so little that they cannot support their family. Thus, Mrs. Khnar S. decided to seek a loan to buy ducklings and food to start breeding ducks. By starting this business, she hopes to earn additional income and to provide a better life for her family. Mrs. Khnar S. is 39 years old and the mother of three children, two of whom are attending school while the other is too young to work or study.

loans.use: To buy ducklings to start a duck breeding business

loans.name: Adakou

texts.fr:
Cette dame âgée de cinquante cinq ans (55) habite le quartier d’adidogomé dans la ville de Lomé capitale du TOGO, elle vend des produits d’alimentation générale dans son quartier, elle exerce ce commerce depuis 1999 et s’approvisionne au marché local d’assiyéyé. Elle n’a jamais obtenu de crédit de chez WAGES et demande son premier crédit pour pouvoir réapprovisionner son stock et bien vendre.
Elle  a  trois (03) enfants qu’elle a à sa charge et avec les revenus de son commerce elle pourra bien prendre en charge sa famille.
texts.en:
This fifty-five-year-old woman lives in the Adidogomé neighborhood of Lomé, the capital of Togo, where she sells foodstuffs. This has been her occupation since 1999, and she buys her stock at the local marketplace of Assiyéyé. She has never had a loan from WAGES before, and requests her first one so she can restock and continue to sell effectively. She has three dependent children, and with the income from her business she will be able to provide well for her family.

Translated from French by Jonah Durning-Hammond, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of foodstuffs

loans.name: Toch

texts.en: Toch S., 45, lives in Siem Reap province, Cambodia. She has owned a plot of land since 1999. She grows both rice and vegetable crops. She can plant her crops twice a year; the dry seaS. and the raining seaS.. Her husband Beung Lem, 46, who is a local fisherman. The couple is responsible for four children. All of them are single and in school. Rice is S.'s main source of income to sustain her family's living expenses. The mature rice seaS. is coming. S. needs to harvest her rice, so that she has requested a loan of $400 as capital to hire a harvester, to harvest her rice crop.

loans.use: to hire a harvester to harvest her rice crop

loans.name: Tantou

texts.fr:
Madame  Tantou  Sow  est âgée de 40 ans, mariée elle vit avec son mari et ses 6 enfants  dans une grande  famille avec d’autres ménages, dans le quartier Missira de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Ayant abandonné l’école  en classe de 9ème (niveau collège)  pour se marier, elle commence à mener plusieurs activités génératrices de revenu auprès de sa mère qui faisait le petit commerce d’articles divers. Depuis maintenant 7 ans, elle a décidé de rester dans ce créneau de commerce d’articles divers telles que la vente de bois de chauffe, de jus et de glace, de chaussures, d’habits, d’huiles alimentaires,  etc. Elle jouit d’une grande réputation et d’une grande clientèle. 
Dans le souci d’augmenter son fonds de commerce elle fait recours à l’institution de microfinance avec qui elle est à son premier prêt individuel.
Elle compte utiliser ce prêt pour acheter, 30 pièces de pagnes Wax, 20 paires de chaussures et 20litres d’huile de palme.
Elle s’approvisionne en matières premières à Bamako(capitale du Mali) ou au Burkina Faso.
Madame Tantou  Sow  vend de façon ambulante et fixe en détail au comptant et à crédit (payable mensuellement pour les habits et hebdomadairement pour l’huile de palme et les chaussures) à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
 Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 25 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour la prise en charge des dépenses familiales. Son ambition est d’ouvrir une boutique d’habits et de chaussures.
texts.en:
Mrs. Tantou S.is 40 years old, married and lives her husband and 6 children in a large family (including other family members) in the Missira neighborhood of Segou ( fourth administrative region in the Republic of Mali ) She left school in the ninth grade to marry and started to earn income through several business activities. Her mother, who had a business selling a variety of articles, taught her the trade. After 7 years, she has decided to remain in the business of selling miscellaneous items, such as fire wood, juice, ice, shoes, clothing, basic oils, etc. She enjoys a great reputation and a large clientele. In an effort to increase her operating capital, she joined the microfinance institute and made her first individual loan. She expects to use this loan to buy 30 pieces of Wax pagne (decorative cloth), 20 pairs of shoes, and 20 liters of palm oil. She buys from first class wholesalers in Bamako ( capital of Mali ) or at Burkina Faso. Mrs Tantou S.goes door to door selling retail for cash or credit (payable monthly for cloths and weekly for palm oil and shoes). Her clientele is made up of both men and women. She expects to make a monthly profit of 25,000 FCFA which will be used to meet family expenses. Her ambition is to open a clothing and shoes boutique.

Translated from French by David Gibbons, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy 30 pieces of Wax pagne (decorative cloth), 20 pairs of shoes, and 20 liters of palm oil

loans.name: Naomi

texts.en:
Naomi is 52 years old. She is single and lives with her parents. Naomi lives at Wasa Simpa, a suburb of Tarkwa, in the Western region of Ghana. 

She loves selling goods, the business through which she obtains her daily source of income.  She has been selling maize cereals for five years to support her family. Maize is one of the favorite staple foods and supplies carbohydrate in the diet.  She takes delivery of her supplies directly from farmers. This enables her to avoid middlemen who would buy from the farmers and resell to her at higher prices. With this loan, she wants to buy bulk supplies of maize to serve her customers. She hopes to use part of her profit to support her business expansion. 

Naomi belongs to a village bank called ‘Me Hwe Awuarde’ which means "Am looking up to God". She also hopes to receive GH¢600 to make her business grow by restocking her inventory.

loans.use: To buy bulk supplies of maize.

loans.name: Rosita

texts.en:
Rosita C. is a farmer. She grows rice which she uses to feed and clothe her family. Rosita is 54 years old and has three children.

Her husband, Eduardo C. is also a farmer. Together, they till their land to support the needs of their family. They started their business in 1993. Until now, they still have their farm, abundant in harvest. "The produce is mainly intended for family use," Rosita said. "And if we have plenty of harvest, I will sell our rice in the market for additional income," she added.

Rosita is asking for a loan of Php 6,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to buy good quality seeds and herbicides to ensure good harvests. The loan will help the couple achieve better yields. In that way, they will be able to pay for school fees like tuition and books.

CEVI is a non-profit organization that helps people start and have their own businesses. CEVI gives its clients credit, training and insurance coverage, to help their small businesses grow.

loans.use: Buy good seeds and herbicides.

loans.name: Tilloboev

texts.ru: Алиев Тешабой проживает в районе Хуросон. Возраст 59 лет, имеет восьмерых  детей. Старшие дети уже взрослые и имеют свои семьи. Сам клиент уже 10 лет торгует бензином. Обратился к нам за кредитом, который планирует использовать для того, чтобы увеличить товарооборот.Получив , кредит он сможет закупить крупную партию бензина и продавать его по доступным ценам , ведь его торговая точка находиться в одном из отдаленных кишлаков.
texts.en:
Teshaboy A. lives in the Hurson region. He is 59 yeas old and has 8 children. His older children are grown up and have their own families. Teshaboy has been in the business of selling gas for the past 10 years. He is asking for a loan so he could purchase a large amount of gas and sell it at affordable prices (his station is located at a distant location).

Translated from Russian by Vasilisa Budnikova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase inventory

loans.name: Julio

texts.es:
El Sr. Julio tiene 45 años, es soltero y posee un taller mecànico en su domicilio. Ademàs de esta actividad cuenta con un omnibus de transporte publico, el cual opera dentro de una empresa dedicada a este rubro.  El credito será de ayuda para la reparacion del omnibus, pues presenta algunos inconvenientes mecanicos que requieren su reparacion inmediata para seguir funcionando normalmente. Teniendo en cuenta que este es el medio de subsistencia de Don Julio. Pues el taller mecanico es muy modesto y no genera ingresos considerables.

El Sr. V. anhela poder adquirir otro omnibus asi como tambièn ampliar su taller mecanico y de esta manera seguir progresando en la vida.
texts.en:
Mr. Julio Vasquez, 45, is single and owns a repair shop out of his home. In addition to this, he has a public omnibus, which he operates for a business dedicated to this area. The loan will help him repair his bus, since it is presenting some inconvenient mechanical issues that require immediate repair to continue normal operation (keeping in mind that this is Mr. V.'s means of living). His repair shop is quite modest and doesn't generate considerable income alone. He hopes to be able to acquire another omnibus as well as grow his repair shop, and so keep progressing in life.

Translated from Spanish by Todd Schmid, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Bus repair

loans.name: Huon

texts.en:
Huon K. is a 26-year-old, married woman. She is the mother of two children, both of whom are teenagers and attend school.

She currently generates an income of approximately $4 per day by selling stone. More specifically, she and her husband first purchase large stone blocks from the people who live near the mountains, then carve and break down the stone blocks into small pieces, and finally sell the stone pieces to people who need them to build their houses. The stone-selling business is the family's main source of income. Huon is now applying for a loan in the amount of $400 to purchase additional stone blocks for resale purposes. In turn, she expects that the loan will enable her to generate additional income.

loans.use: To expand and improve her business by purchasing additional stone blocks

loans.name: Reyna Francisaca

texts.es:
La dama Reyna Francisca E., se dedica a atender su negocio de venta de frutas y de verduras en el Mercado Central de la ciudad de Chinandega donde a diario se dedica arduamente a desarrollar su actividad.

Ella ha logrado salir adelante gracias al apoyo que Ceprodel le ha brindado y es por esta razón que espera muy confiadamente que su nuevo crédito que ha solicitado le sea otorgado y así mejorar su situación económica.
texts.en:
Reyna Francisca E. earns her living selling fruits and vegetables in the Central Market in the city of Chinandega, where she works very hard at her business every day. She has succeeded in getting ahead thanks to the support she gets from Ceprodel, so she is very hopeful that she will be granted the new loan she is seeking, which will allow her to improve her economic situation.

Translated from Spanish by Jill Heske, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Junrey

texts.en:
Junrey E. is from the village of Sugbongcogon, Tagoloan Misamis Oriental. He is 30 years old and is married. To make a living, Junrey owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a "sari-sari" variety store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income from the business comes primarily from selling a variety of products in the local community. He also provides transportation services using his motorcycle. Junrey has been engaged in his business for over 7 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Junrey joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and the ability to engage in business activities. Junrey is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell, and a portion of it will be used for maintenance for his motorcycle. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Junrey from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support his family's needs.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell, and motorcycle maintenance.

loans.name: Anita

texts.en:
Anita B. is from the village of Brgy. Yumbing, Mambajao Camiguin. She is 42 years old. Anita is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Anita owns and operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling green bananas, vegetables and fruit including beverages, in the local community. Anita has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 1,000 PHP a month for these activities.

Anita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Anita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. Anita is requesting a new loan of 6000 PHP, which will be used to expand the business. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Anita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To expand the business

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes is a member of the Kisiwani borrower group in Kola, Morogoro. She is 23 years old and single.

Agnes started her own food business selling poks one year ago. She works 10 hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 100,000 Tanzania shillings.

This is Agnes’s first loan from BRAC Tanzania. She has requested 150,000 Tsh in order to to expand her business. With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Agnes hopes to save money and pay school fees.

loans.use: To buy more poks (a food item) to sell

loans.name: El Carmen Group

texts.es:
El grupo el Carmen está formado por Doña Jerónima Alejandrina R., Rosibel Angélica T. M., Yamileth del Carmen C. G. y Álvaro de Jesús C. G.. Quienes provienen de una pequeña Comarca llamada San Francisco, ubicada en los alrededores de la Ciudad de Nindiri.

Doña Jerónima de 37 años de edad, es la coordinadora del grupo, una mujer de origen muy humilde, que no sabe leer, debido a que nació en un hogar de suma pobreza que le impidió estudiar y por consiguiente desde muy pequeña aprendió a subsistir con arduo trabajo. A muy corta edad aprendió el oficio de elaboración de tortillas con el que se sostuvo por largos años de su vida. Esto hasta que su esposo le animo a iniciar un negocio de venta de calculadoras, le enseño como invertir y como ver las ganancias de una manera eficaz.

Jerónima tiene 4 hijos de los cuales actualmente solo dos están estudiando, debido a que los mayores se desmotivaron de hacerlo, por eso sueña con poder aprender a leer y a pesar de su edad posee la convicción de lograr su sueño y con esto motivar a sus hijos mayores a superarse y así mejorar sus condiciones de vida.

Este Grupo está iniciando el Onceavo ciclo de crédito y están muy contentos de poder seguir adelante, ya que con éstos se les ha facilitado el crecimiento de sus negocios.

Doña Rosibel T. vende frutas y verduras ambulante en Masaya y tiene tres hijos a los que espera sacar adelante; Doña Yamileth C. es profesora de educación primaria, pero debido a la difícil situación económica que se enfrenta en la actualidad, inicio un negocio de venta de Helados y Hielos en su casa y distribuye en  su comarca ropa interior por encargo y Don Álvaro vende en el Mercado de Masaya Granos Básicos.
texts.en:
The El Carmen group is composed of Doña Jerónima Alejandrina R., Rosibel Angélica T. M., Yamileth del Carmen C. G., and Álvaro de Jesús C. G. who come from a small area called San Francisco located near the town of Nindiri. 37-year old Doña Jerónima is the coordinator of the group. She comes from a humble background and doesn’t know how to read as she was born into a very poor home and was unable to go to school. Consequently, ever since she was a little girl, she learned to survive by working very hard. At a very young age she learned how to make tortillas which kept her going for many years. She did this until her husband encouraged her to start a business selling calculators. He taught her some business skills and how to deal with the money she earned. Jerónima has four children, two of whom are still in school. The two older ones lost interest. For this reason she dreams of learning to read, and in spite of her age she is determined to fulfil this dream and thus motivate her older children to better themselves and improve their lives. This group is starting its eleventh loan cycle, and they are very happy to be able to continue since with the money they have been able to expand their businesses. Doña Rosibel T. sells fruit and vegetables in the streets of Masaya. She has three children who she hopes will do well in life. Doña Yamileth C. is a primary teacher, but because of the difficult economic situation which she is currently experiencing, she started a business selling ice-cream and ice from her house. She also sells underwear in the neighbourhood. Don Álvaro sells grain in the Masaya market.

Translated from Spanish by Jane Agg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy merchandise

loans.name: José Daniel

texts.es:
En el departamento de Masaya, el señor José Daniel G. se dedica a su actividad de elaboración y venta de calzados ofreciendo el producto tanto a niños como a damas y caballeros. Se ha destacado en esta actividad con la que mantiene a su familia compuesta por su conyuge y sus dos hijos.

El motivo por el que acudió a Ceprodel es para solicitar un crédito para la compra de los materiales de trabajo para continuar en la elaboración de los calzados y así seguir llevando el sustento a su mesa. Él trabaja con su propia maquina de coser la cual la adquirió por medio de sus ahorros de largo tiempo.
texts.en:
In the district of Masaya, Sr. José Daniel G. manufactures and sells shoes for children, as well as women and men. This business allows him to support his wife and two children.

He came to CEPRODEL to request a loan so that he can buy materials for making shoes, which will allow him to continue feeding his family. He works with his own sewing machine, which he purchased with money that he saved up over time.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer
